title: US Congress approves release of Epstein files, putting matter before Trump | The World | ABC NEWS
description: A bill to force the release of the Jeffrey Epstein files has passed the US congress after a near-unanimous house vote. The legislation will next go to President Donald Trump, who has indicated he will sign the bill into law after backing down from his fierce opposition to it over the weekend. The Hill's Julia Manchester tells The World it's still unclear if the bill has made its way from the Senate to the White House. title: Bangladesh political tensions spark concerns for garment industry | The World | ABC NEWS
description: Many Bangladesh locals have welcomed the death penalty handed down in absentia to the country's exiled former leader. Sheikh Hasina was found guilty of ordering the killing of hundreds of student protesters last year. But as Loughlin Patrick reports, the political uncertainty since then has taken a toll on some of the country's biggest industries, with concerns the court ruling could flare up tensions. title: House prices and rents to keep rising in 2026, says Domain | The Business | ABC NEWS
description: A gradual rise in household incomes is one reason why house prices are expected to reach record highs in all capital cities by the end of next year.  That's according to Domain's forecast report for 2026. It shows house prices will rise by 6 per cent across the capitals, compared to 9 per cent this year.  Units will go up by 5 per cent, in a market that's expected to be more balanced and policy-driven. Domain's chief of research and economics Nicola Powell says the forecast for growth is largely due to the expansion of the first home guarantee scheme. She says the first half of next year will likely see first home buyers competing with investors, but as capital growth starts to slow, investors will likely pull back. Domain's report reveals the biggest increase in house prices will be seen in the most rate-sensitive cities of Sydney and Melbourne.  Nicola Powell says Sydney's median house price is expected to hit $1.9 million in 2026, and setting a pathway for a $2 million median house price in Sydney by 2027. Rental price growth is also forecast across all capital cities, however Nicola Powell says she would describe the projects as modest and in line with inflation. "We're expecting a little bit of an uptick in the rate of rental price growth in Sydney and Melbourne for house rents, but in most of our capital cities, we're expecting unit rents to grow faster than house rents", she says. "That really is this steer towards more affordable rental properties, smaller rental properties because we know the rental market has been extremely strained over recent years." #ABCBusiness Subscribe: http://ab.co/1svxLVE  ABC NEWS provides around the clock coverage of news events as they break in Australia and abroad. title: Pam Bondi says Trump administration will 'follow the law' on Epstein bill | ABC NEWS
description: A bill requiring the US Department of Justice to release files on Jeffrey Epstein is now with the president, who may sign it as early as today.  Trump recently changed his position on releasing the Epstein files after internal pressure from Republicans.  The bill passed Congress quickly, receiving near-unanimous approval in the House and swiftly advancing through the Senate. Attorney General Pam Bondi says the Trump administration will 'follow the law' when it comes to how it moves forward with the files. title: Meta tells teens to 'download or delete' as it moves deadline to Dec 4 | ABC NEWS
description: Meta has begun telling Instagram, Facebook and Threads users it believes are younger than 16 years old they have two weeks left to download their data. Account holders who want to fight their removal will have to undergo facial scans or provide ID to prove they are old enough. Meta is aiming to remove hundreds of thousands of accounts by the December 10 deadline, with the first accounts disappearing on December 4. title: How Donald Trump lost control of the Epstein files | ABC News Daily podcast
description: The remaining Epstein files are finally set to be released after a vote in US Congress and a shift in the US President’s position.    Despite dismissing calls to release files related to the late convicted sex offender Jeffrey Epstein for months, Donald Trump reversed course when it became clear a bill to compel the release would pass in the US House of Representatives.    Today, David A Graham, staff writer at The Atlantic, on how Trump was backed into a corner and what it says about his leadership and support among his MAGA base.   Featured:    David A Graham, staff writer at The Atlantic

description: The Israeli military has stepped up its attacks against Hamas and Hezbollah, launching airstrikes in southern Lebanon. It comes as Israel continues to build a concrete wall on its border which Lebanon says strays into its territory. title: Russian strikes kill at least 25, including children, in western Ukraine | ABC NEWS
description: At least 25 people, including three children, were killed in a major Russian attack on western Ukraine. Hundreds of drones and missiles struck targets in Ternopil, damaging apartment complexes and injuring over 70 people.  Rescuers worked to free victims from smoke-filled buildings, while energy facilities and infrastructure in nearby areas were also hit. title: Woman told to cordon off backyard, access to house, after using coloured sand | ABC NEWS
description: For the past two years Mrs Reading's family has used one of the coloured sand products, which were recalled last week due to potential asbestos contamination, for their rangoli artworks to celebrate the Hindu Diwali festival.   They later swept the sand across and between the pavers in their backyard. So when Mrs Reading read about the recall she was thrown into a panic.   She said that when she contacted WorkSafe ACT, she was told to cordon off the area and pay for an asbestos company to remove the sand.   Mrs Reading says it is frustrating when the advice given to parents on the issue is impractical and called on the ACT government, "to give advice that people could actually follow." title: Gustav Klimt painting sells for AUD$366 million at auction | ABC NEWS
description: A portrait of Elisabeth Lederer by Vienna Successionist Artist, Gustav Klimt has sold at a Sotheby's auction for $366 million AU ($US236 million).  The 20th-century art work was part of the Leonard A. Lauder Collection and has recorded the second highest price for an artwork sold at auction.  Art Historian Professor Donna Brett explains who commissioned the artwork, why it would attract such a high price and why it was seized by Nazi officials. title: Toyah's Murder: Close friend says alleged killer acted 'nervously' | ABC NEWS
description: Multiple witnesses who were at Wangetti Beach the day Toyah Cordingley was murdered have described what and who they saw that day. In this episode, Chris and Stocky talk through their evidence, as well as evidence from a close friend of Rajwinder Singh's, describing the alleged murderer's behaviour before he fled the country. If you have any questions you'd like Chris and Stocky to answer in future episodes, please email thecaseof@abc.net.au (mailto:thecaseof@abc.net.au) .
